column4: I installed MATLAB and I cannot find it.  Can I search for the program through termal and execute it?
Do you know what the binary is named?
no.  I dont know what that means,
If the installer was made properly, it should be installed in /opt.  See if there's anything in /opt
just cd /opt?
Sure.  Or ls /opt.
if you cd in, you'll have to ls afterwards, of course.
only think in opt is gogle
I remember it was something like /usr/local/matlab
or /usr/local/bin/ matlab
Oh ok.  So cd into /usr/local and ls.  If there's a matlab directory, ls it.  If not, ls -lhtr|tail /usr/local/bin/

ls -lhtr means, long listing, human readable, sorted by time, reverse.  So the most recently created file will show up at the bottom of the list.  And tail will (by dfeault) only give you the last few lines.
can I search for matlab?
Sure.  find /usr/ -iname "matlab*" -type f
That may help you.
can I search for matlab?
matlab is not in the directory I thought it was.  Can I search for it in general?
That was the find command I gave you.
find /usr -iname "matlab*" -type f
That's find all files (not directories) with names starting with matlab.
but isnt that only for things under /usr?
yes.  Pop quiz, how would you change it to search for everything on your system?
